headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phillus. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. J.P. Bilbrey, President and CEO; and Bert Alfonso, President, International and Head of Mergers and Acquisitions, will provide yo
componenttext:
Thank you, Phillus. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. J.P. Bilbrey, President and CEO; and Bert Alfonso, President, International and Head of Mergers and Acquisitions, will provide you with an overview of our results followed by a Q&A session.
Let me remind everyone listening that today's conference call may contain statements which are forward-looking. These statements are based on current expectations, which are subject to risk and uncertainty. Actual results may vary materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements because of factors such as those listed in this morning's press release and in our 10-K for 2013 filed with the SEC.
If you have not seen a press release, a copy is posted on our corporate website in the Investor Relations section. Included in the press release is a consolidated balance sheet and a summary of consolidated statements of income prepared in accordance with GAAP.
Within the Notes section of the press release, we have provided adjusted pro forma reconciliations of select income statement line items quantitatively reconciled to GAAP. The company uses these non-GAAP measures as key metrics for evaluating performance internally. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to replace the presentation of financial results in accordance with GAAP. Rather, the company believes the presentation of earnings, excluding certain items, provides additional information to investors to facilitate the comparison of past and present operations.
As a result, we will discuss 2014 fourth quarter results, excluding net pretax charges of $32.5 million or $0.32 per share diluted, primarily related to noncash trade market impairment charge amount on disposal of $24.8 million or $0.10 per share diluted and business realignment costs of $4.7 million or $0.02 per share diluted. Our discussion of any future projections will also exclude the impact of these net charges.
With that out of the way, let me turn the call over to J.P. Bilbrey.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning to all of you on the phone and webcast. In 2014, Hershey made progress against its strategic initiatives. U.S. CMG xAOC+C market share reached 31.4%, up 0.3 share points versus last year. We acquired Shanghai Golden Monkey, which more tha
componenttext:
Good morning to all of you on the phone and webcast. 
In 2014, Hershey made progress against its strategic initiatives. U.S. CMG xAOC+C market share reached 31.4%, up 0.3 share points versus last year. 
We acquired Shanghai Golden Monkey, which more than doubled the company's presence in China. We expanded into stacks and with the launch of Hershey's spreads and the related as Graham dippers, and we sourced 30% of our cocoa needs from certified and sustainable cocoa farms, putting us in a solid positioned to deliver on our 100% goal by 2020.
There were also challenges. In 2014, we believe lower retail store traffic, changes in consumers spending pattern as a result of the snack program and a more competitive snacking environment were contributing factors impacting how consumers participated in the snack segment. This resulted in fourth quarter and full year sales and earnings that were below our expectations.
Specifically, growth in snacking alternatives and in evolving retail landscape or packing how consumers buy and where and how they make purchases. Higher income consumers continued to ask for simple ingredients, health and wellness; and millennials view brands and brand attributes beyond traditional transparency to include social responsibility. 
They are also interacting with media differently.
Now let me share with you some of the things that we're doing to address this. Our R&D and innovation teams continue to make progress on new confectionery and snack products that enable us to offer a great confectionery products and increase the breadth of our portfolio. 
Later this year, the Club Channel will be introducing Brookside dark chocolate fruit and nuts snack bars. 
Building on our snacks and adjacency strategy, earlier today, we announced that we entered into an agreement to acquire KRAVE Jerky, which enables us to enter the rapidly growing meat snacks category. We're really excited about this acquisition and the opportunity to participate in the $2.5 billion meat snacks category that's growing at a double rate. While snacks and adjacencies is a lever in our long-term sales algorithm, we're very focused on confectionery. It's who we are, and it's our namesake. We have a lot of CMG innovation this year that I'll talk to in a moment, but we also have a meaningful new product pipeline that gives me confidence that innovation can continue to contribute at least 1 point of growth to our net sales algorithm on an annual basis. So I remain bullish on the CMG category and our ability to keep increasing market share. 
As it relates to simple ingredients and transparency, we've actually done a lot of work here. We have leveraged what we've done as our plan is to move a large portion of our portfolio in this direction. We're building the capability and have made progress to source non-GMO sugar and RSVT-free milk for products in the United States. We've already begun this work with key sourcing suppliers here in the U.S., and we'll have more news on this later in the year.
On the media front we expected advertising and related consumer promotion will increase at a rate greater than sales. Included in this is a greater proportion of investment in digital advertising on programs, consumers view on their mobile devices via traditional networks, user-generated content and sources like Buzz . So we're making investments like will benefit the company in the near and long-term. But we'll have more in this in CAGNY, so let's move on.
I was satisfied with improved results in the convenience store, large mass retail and dollar store channels, especially in the second half of the year. However, FDMx nonseasonal candy performance was not in line with our initial plans. Lower retail store traffic, greater levels of in-store activity by broader snacking manufacturers and continued economic challenges for a segment of consumers in these channels impacted our nonseasonal candy growth. Looking at total xAOC+C-store takeaway, U.S. market place performance sequentially improved throughout the year. Hershey fourth quarter retail takeaway of 3.8% was greater than the category growth of 2.2% resulting in a market share gain of 0.5 points. Marketplace performance was greater than 4Q net sales given solid Halloween and holiday sales, a portion of which shipped in the third quarter; the timing of the buying related to the price increases as a portion of third quarter net sales would have normally occurred in the fourth quarter; and the lapping of the strong year-ago period with select retailers increase inventory levels. 
Driving our fourth quarter takeaway results were improvements in convenience stores, large mass retail and dollar stores. These were the channels were many of our second half initiatives were focused, so I was pleased with the results. 
The programming and execution changes we made in the FDMx and Club Channel simply require a longer lead time to impact in-store merchandising activity. Hence, our sales mix and lower-than-forecast category growth impacted profitability and margins.
Let me now talk about 2015, where our focus will be on restoring our U.S. momentum. 
We have a solid line-up of products that will bring variety, news and excitement in the category. In addition to the carryover benefit of Brookside Crunchy Clusters and Reese's spreads, we're also launching Kit Kat White Minis, Hershey's Caramels, Ice Breakers Cool Blast Chews, Reese's Spreads, Snackters, Graham Dippers and some other yet-to-be-announced new products. 
Additionally, the Reese's brand is leveraging its NCAA relationship and has become an official sponsor of ESPN College Football Game Day. These initiatives are tied into the customers specific merchandising programs and big core brands that should result in higher quality merchandising versus last year. 
Additionally, we're increasing our reach as we're adding incremental headcount to our sales force that will result in hours in store being up mid-single digits. We'll complement this with increased levels of advertising that I mentioned earlier. We believe the investments we're making across our business positions us for future growth. The dynamics of the confectionery category, impulsivity, conversion rate at checkouts, season multiple pep types are all in advantage. As a result, in 2015, we anticipate that the plans we have in place will help mitigate the volume elasticity related to the price increase and that will outpace the category, and again, gain market share. 
Let me now provide you with some information on our International business. For the full year, our international net sales increased nearly 15%, including the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates and positive contribution of about $54  million for the Shanghai Golden Monkey. Excluding SGM and unfavorable FX, international net sales increased 10%, a solid number but less than our expectations due to macro economic headwinds that have yet to subside and will most likely remain a challenge this year. 
The Hershey, Golden Monkey integration work is underway and on track.
In 2015, we'll distribute acquired confectionery and protein-based bean-curd snacks into the China modern trade, and we expect to have deeper Tier 2 city coverage of some Hershey chocolate products. We're also leveraging newly acquired manufacturing capabilities.
In China, Brazil, Mexico and India, we've made solid progress against our planned initiatives of investing in go-to-market capabilities and portfolio expansions. In select markets, we launched Reese's, and it's off to a good start. Additionally, we're testing additional products as we looked to build out our global brands over the next few years. 
Therefore, in 2015, including a negative impact from foreign currency exchange rates and excluding the impact of M&A, we expect international net sales growth to increase around 10%.
Including SGM, reported international net sales are expected to be around $1.2 billion by the end of 2015.
By country, our chocolate business in China had a solid year. Chocolate category growth in 2014 was about 12%. Historically, the chocolate category has increased 10% to 11% in the fourth quarter. However, it slowed to around 8% as we see less gifting behind the government policy changes.
Hershey fourth quarter retail takeaway of about 20% was less than our expectation. Importantly, our market share in Q4 increased to full point  to around 11%. In Mexico, chocolate category growth in the modern trade 2014 was around 1%. The category and consumer struggle during the year although trends were better in the second half of the year with chocolate category growth of 3%. But this is still below the historical growth rate of 7% to 8%. Hershey Mexico chocolate retail takeaway for the year was up around 2%, resulting in a market share gain of 0.3 points.
We expect 2015 to be better in last year, albeit in a continuing challenging environment. 
Our performance in Brazil sequentially improved as the year progressed. For the year, Brazil chocolate category growth was 1% versus about 5% in recent years. Hershey retail takeaway was up 2%. Our performance was driven by our Hershey tablet bar growth and the launch of Reese's. 
We'll look to build on this in 2015.
Now to wrap up. Our consumer and customer plans as well as our investment profile for 2015 clearly reflect the learnings from 2014. Our plans are focused and the investment profile is concentrated in the areas to leverage Hershey's advantage brands and go-to-market strength. Investment in our brands, innovation and capabilities as well as an increase across all channels and merchandising and programming positions the company to compete effectively in confectionery and across the broader snack continuum.
We believe these investments should generate organic net sales growth or constant currency sales, excluding M&A and FX impacts of around 4% to 6% in 2015. This is less than our previous estimate and reflects the macroeconomic headwinds in international markets and the slowly improving U.S. nonseasonal trends. 
I typically just talked to net sales with or without M&A. However, when we established our long-term sales target, we didn't anticipate the U.S. dollar being this strong. Given the current backdrop, we expect foreign exchange rates to be greater than our previous estimate and be about 1 percentage point unfavorable in 2015. We estimate that the net contribution from acquisitions and divestitures will be around 2.5 points.
We continue to focus on growth initiatives and margin opportunities behind continuous productivity improvement initiatives. With the conclusion of the project Next Century program, in 2015, we'll focus on where the next largest opportunities are for future incremental productivity and cost savings. A portion of any particular savings from this assessment would be reinvested in our CMG and snacks business to accelerate our growth. And we'll provide more information on this at the upcoming CAGNY conference. I will now turn it over to Bert, who will provide some additional details on our financial results. Bert?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, J.P., and good morning to everyone. It's a pleasure to be here to talk about our results as well as some of the recent M&A activity. As Mark mentioned, I've been pretty close to all of this, as I have responsibility for the M&A function a
componenttext:
Well, thank you, J.P., and good morning to everyone. It's a pleasure to be here to talk about our results as well as some of the recent M&A activity. As Mark mentioned, I've been pretty close to all of this, as I have responsibility for the M&A function as well as our international segment. So let's get started. 
Fourth quarter net sales of $2 billion increased 2.7% versus last year, generating adjusted earnings per share diluted of $1.04, an increased 20.9%. As J.P. stated, the sales increase was lower than our expectations, primarily due to lower retail store traffic. Net price realization, mostly in the U.S., was a 3.1-point benefit. Excluding Shanghai Golden Monkey, volume was off 2.3 points due to price elasticity associated with the U.S. price increase announced in July and lower-than-expected nonseasonal sales. 
The Shanghai Golden Monkey acquisition was a 2.7-point benefit and foreign currency was a 0.8-point headwinds. 
Q4 U.S. seasonal sales, primarily driven by holiday, increased high single digits on a percentage basis versus last year. Full year seasonal sales were a bp higher given a later Easter in 2014. 
Conversely, Easter is 15-day shorter in 2015 and will be a headwind this year. From a marketplace perspective, our Halloween and holiday market share increased 0.9 points and 1.1 points, respectively. 
International net sales in the fourth quarter increased 28%, including a benefit of about $54 million related to the Shanghai Golden Monkey acquisition. Excluding Shanghai Golden Monkey, international net sales increased 8% as reported and 11% on a constant currency basis, as unfavorable FX was greater than anticipated. Macro economic headwinds in Q4 led to international sales being lower than our expectations.
Turning to margins. Fourth quarter adjusted gross margin increased by 30 basis points. The increase is driven by net price realization, slightly favorable input costs and supply chain productivity, partially offset by unfavorable sales mix and other supply chain costs. 
Fourth quarter adjusted earnings before interest and taxes or EBIT increased 17.5% versus last year, generating an adjusted EBIT margin of 18.7%, a 240-basis-point increase versus last year. The increase is due to higher gross margin and lower SM&A cost that declined about 5% due primarily to lower employee-related costs.
In Q4, advertising was at about as the same as last year. As we said throughout the year, advertising GRPs were up mid-single digits on a percentage basis versus 2013. Now let me provide a bit more detail on our International business. China continues to drive international net sales growth and excluding Shanghai Golden Monkey increased about 35% in both the fourth quarter and for the full year. We anticipated similar profile in 2015. I am very pleased with the progress we continue to make in China and remain optimistic regarding confectionery growth in both the modern and traditional trade. We will continue to expand our selling capabilities and expect growth in 2015 to be balanced between velocity and distribution gains. We will also expand cross selling of products between Shanghai Golden Monkey and Hershey China in the coming year.
And Finally, we were very pleased  with our 1.6-point share gain in chocolate in 2014.
In Brazil, Q4 net sales were about the same as last year on a reported basis, an increase of about 12% on a constant currency basis. For the full year, net sales declined about 3% on a reported basis and increased about 7% on a constant currency basis versus last year. Despite the difficult category environment, we were pleased with a small share gain of 0.1 points. In 2015, we're exploring other go-to-market options together with our current JV partner, . Our distribution JV with has enabled us to double our market share over the last few years, however, we are considering having total control of the selling and distribution function to give us more flexibly and investment options. 
In Mexico, fourth quarter net sales declined 6% on a reported basis, and we're flat on a constant currency basis versus last year. For the full year, net sales declined 8% on a reported basis and 4% on a constant currency basis compared to 2013.
Again our chocolate performance was favorable with a 0.3-point share gain, driven by both velocity and distribution gains. Trends in Mexico are getting better, and we expect continued improvements throughout 2015 although still below the historical growth rates.
We have made solid progress against our international strategic plans; we remain committed to our core markets; and we'll continue to make the necessary investments to build distribution capability, brand equity and drive trial and repeat purchases.
Moving down the P&L. Fourth quarter interest expense is $21 million was about the same as last year. For the full year, interest expense was $85 million and in line with our expectations. And for 2015, we expect interest expense to be $75 million to $80 million. The invested tax rate for the fourth quarter and the full year was 34.5% in line with our estimates. 
In 2015, we expect the adjusted tax rate to be similar to last year. In the fourth quarter, with average shares outstanding on a diluted basis were approximately $223.5 million, leading to adjusted earnings per share diluted of $1.04 and increases 20.9%.
Full year adjusted EBIT increased 5.8% versus last year, generating an adjusted EBIT margin of 19.6% or a 40-basis-point increase. The increase was driven by lower SG&A.
Turning now to the balance sheet and to our cash flow. At the end of the fourth quarter, net trading capital increased versus last year's fourth quarter by $240 million. Accounts receivable was higher by $119 million, primarily due to the Shanghai Golden Monkey acquisition, China consolidation and traditional credit terms provided to our largest customers in China. Inventory was higher by $141 million to the Shanghai Golden Monkey in as well as higher raw material inventory levels, primary in dairy, that we mentioned in the last quarter. And accounts payable increased by $21 million. 
Capital additions, including software, were $139 million in the fourth quarter and $379 million for the full year, in line with our expectations. This included capital related to our manufacturing facility that we are building in Johor, Malaysia. In 2015, we expect CapEx to be in the $375 million to $400 million range. The company repurchased 2 million of outstanding shares in the fourth quarter and 202 million for the full year. Repurchases of $125 million were against the prior authorization, and $77 million were against the current $250 million repurchase authorization approved in February of 2014.
In addition, 32 million common shares were repurchased in Q4 to replace shares issued in connection with the exercise of stock options. Depreciation and amortization was $59 million in the fourth quarter and $212 million for the full year, in line with expectations. Dividends paid during the quarter were $115 million and $440 million for the full year. Cash and short-term investments at the end of fourth quarter were $471 million, slightly below our expectations due to the lower sales. The company remains well positioned to fund our dividends, working capital, capital expenditure requirements and acquisitions.
Let me close by providing context into our 2015 outlook. As J.P. summarized, in 2015, we have a solid pipeline of targeted innovation, merchandising and programming that can drive pack type and channel growth. In addition, advertising and related consumer marketing expense is expected to increase at a rate greater than net sales growth. As a result, we expect 2015 net sales to increase from 5.5% to 7.5%, including the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates and a net contribution from acquisitions and divestitures of about 2.5 points. 
This includes the acquisition of Shanghai Golden Monkey and Alan Candy that goes in the fourth quarter as well as the ventured into the last month to acquire KRAVE Jerky and divest Mauna Loa. We expect the trade on Mauna Loa transactions to close in the first quarter. Excluding that acquisitions and divestitures, sales were expected to increase 3% to 5%. This is lower than our previous estimate due to the continued macroeconomic headwinds as well as greater-than-initial estimates related to unfavorable foreign currency exchange rates. And we expect foreign exchange impact to be greater than our previous estimate and have an unfavorable impact of approximately 1 percentage point on our full year net sales growth.
We continue to have a significant focus on gross margin and expect the previously announced pricing action as well as productivity and cost savings to result in 2015 gross margin expansion of 135 to 145 basis points. Adjusted earnings per share diluted are expected to increase 8% to 10% and that includes dilution from acquisition and divestitures of $0.03 to $0.05 per share.
Before we open up for Q&A, just a couple thoughts on the first quarter. Remember that Easter is 2 weeks shorter this year and being sold on the old price points, which will pressure both margins. Our international sales profile is similar to prior years with annual growth, primarily driven by second half. Therefore, total first quarter net sales, including M&A, are expected to be around the low end of our annual sales target.
Additionally, brand building as well as investments and capabilities will ramp up in Q1. Given all these moving parts, EPS growth is expected to be pressured in the first quarter and higher as the year progresses. I thank you for your time this morning, and we'll now take questions.

componenttext: So I guess I had a question about when looking into next year and sort  of the parts of the revenue, the drags on revenue relative to target right now are -- aside from FX are the nonseasonal confections business in the U.S. and the international -- collectively the international business is below long-term targets. So if you could talk about first on the nonseasonal business, are you seeing any sequential improvement like in January or so far year-to-date? Just simply because you've got some pressure like gas prices are lower, jobless numbers look better? This sort of insights into how nonseasonal is maybe tracking as you move into the first quarter?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's a couple -- sure, yes, there's a couple of things. We are encouraged with some of the things we're seeing as we deconstruct the weekly data. So you're correct. The nonseasonal FDMX sales has been the biggest drag in our business. So we feel g
componenttext: Yes. There's a couple -- sure, yes, there's a couple of things. We are encouraged with some of the things we're seeing as we deconstruct the weekly data. So you're correct. The nonseasonal FDMX sales has been the biggest drag in our business. So we feel good about the fact that in the fourth quarter we saw improvement, we continue to grow ahead of the category, and it was really a result of we think improved focus in merchandising in specific channels. In FDMX it's a slower build there because the planning cycle is also different. But there's a couple of things that we're seeing and if we look at the weekly data and when you get the most recent quad you're going to see that we're making good progression from a share standpoint. We think that reflect some of the changes we made in merchandising. One of the other things that we're seeing is as if trips continue to be negative although they're getting better but negative, and of course, that continues to affect the ends of consumer because this is all everyday business. Because people in the story lose that instant consumer piece. So we're very focused on that. There's 8 piece of data that I recently looked at for our brand specifically that within there's an increase in  actual purchase size. So the trips that we're getting purchase size is actually up. The one caveat I'll make with that is keep in mind with the fourth quarter you have some seasonal influence so that can be part of it. But in the weekly data, and this is all information, we do have some real encouragement there. So I feel good about what I'm beginning to see. Anecdotally, as you talk to retailers, I would say that I'm hearing some of those same kinds of sentiments echoed and then of course, we all are aware that the consumers had a lot of pressure at the bottom of the economic pyramid, and it's still yet to be seen how that consumer participates in the market. But for the total, I think I'm encouraged.

We also had a little pressure on our export business, which was not huge. It is very profitable, and as you can imagine, the currency into somebody's market also has some impact.

You mentioned Easter wasn't about what percent would that be? Related to that and secondly is there some negative mix factor I'm missing on why gross margins would only be up 120 or 130 gross margin Do you accept this magnitude of price increase? Your #2 commodity, dairy, is now in free fall, and I know you've bought forward to some extent, that's understandable but it looks to me like your cost bucket flat to down exiting the year. Is there something I'm missing as to why that margin expansion is so small? And how that might take over the year? And then third and finally, can you give us a sense what kind of volume you're thinking all associated with this guidance? componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me kind of take pricing one first, and then I'll let Bert talk a little bit about the gross margin. The best way to think about the pricing is that as we move through the year, there is still some activities that are under the old price certainly
componenttext: Yes. Let me kind of take pricing one first, and then I'll let Bert talk a little bit about the gross margin. The best way to think about the pricing is that as we move through the year, there is still some activities that are under the old price certainly around the seasonal business. So you'll begin to see that have a greater impact in Q2 and Q3, and then as you think about getting through the end of '15, we continue to model the elasticity at about 1-1 rate in terms of volume and price. So by the time we get to the first quarter of 2016 from our modeling would suggest that we're back to a whole environment or back to 100 in terms of volume contribution to our growth. So that's the way I would think about it broadly. There's a lot of movement still. But as we look at some of our channel modeling there's nothing that we're seeing that would cause us to believe that we would be any different than how we planned it. As you know, when you are increasing advertising in the various rapid rate back in 2008, '09 and 2011, there might have been a little bit of a faster conversion rate, but we think the way we've currently modeled it is probably about right.

Obviously, you might have some of your lower hedges rolling off and are going to a little bit higher market. And what we've seen some improvement recently and that's good. We still have Cocoa that's higher than '14 levels. So that does have some -- a bit of an impact in terms of how you're thinking about the expansion. And the other thing is, as J.P. mentioned, our profile for 2015 is driven by pricing. So we are expecting 5 to 6 points of pricing and 1 to  2 points of lower volume. That lower volume does pressure our absorption of the plant so you don't get the full benefit of that until you get later in the year, as J.P. mentioned, we start to recover the prepress preprice volume. So some volume impact as we worked through the price elasticity and whilst some commodities are clearly in a better place like dairy and sugar, we do still have higher cocoa prices year-on-year so that's helping to mitigate to some degree what might be otherwise larger gross margin expansion.

componenttext: Yes, thanks, J.P. mentioned, we're seeing consumers continue to snack more and throughout the day and as such, their snacking needs are really evolving. So as we look at that marketplace, clearly, one of the categories that's really meeting consumers needs is meat snacks. Meat snacks is a category that is one of the fastest growing, growing double-digit in the U.S. this past year and over the past several years. Household penetration is expanding. So household penetration is only about 31% but it continues to grow, 32 points this past. So clearly it's meeting a lot of consumer needs. And as we looked to that category,  KRAVE was interesting to us because KRAVE is really playing in the fastest-growing segment of the meat snacks category, the better-for-you premium segment. So we really like the brand. We think it has tremendous potential. The product proposition has a unique point of difference with a great taste of texture. It's a  culinary inspired kind of profile, and we think that there's a lot of potential, and they continue to bring new consumers into the meat snacks category in the marketplace for us to leverage Hershey's strengths in supply chain but you might say it's the retail to really drive the business. So we couldn't be more excited about how it will continue to help us to meet consumers needs as we stayed very focused, of course, on winning in our category.

componenttext: Yes. I think, Eric, if you look historically the premium, we sort of defined it over time is somewhere around 7% or 8% of the total category. In good economic times it always tends to grow and expand in terms of space, some of that growth is driven by distribution and then in more difficult economic times usually the distribution in category contraction goes along with it. I think what it speaks to in the current environment is the top end of the economic pyramid is fine and the consumer that participates there has the ability to participate. And I also think that part of the category has, in many ways, a clear message to the consumer, also, is around sometimes ingredients and so forth. So I've believe that that's what we're seeing more than anything else. I agree with you, we've not done a good job in the premium space. We're spending a lot of time right now on how we want to participate in premium. We're pushing up some within our middle of our portfolio certainly with products like Brookside, which takes us up a little bit. You'll see some of the innovation we have this year, which we'll also do that. And then we're looking strongly at our brands like Scharffenberger and trying to make an effort to see how we can play differently with those brands. So we're not going to ignore that. I think in the past, we have not done a good job. We want to reorient ourselves a bit there. And then it's still problematic for the consumers  that are participating in the category. So you will see some category expansion from that space but I think that the overall category really will continue to be driven by mass products.

componenttext: Well, first, I'd tell you, it feels challenging everyday. But I think the way to think about it is we feel good about our long-term guidance. We know that there's going to be these periods of times where there's pressure on businesses and as we look back, I'm sure over our 120-year history, and I remember hearing people talk about cocoa being a $7,000 a ton and the world was going to end. There are always these periods of times which would seem more challenging maybe than others. But if you think about our footprint and our portfolio, the countries that we're focused against despite there maybe currency headwinds and these kinds of things, these are some of the best high-growth GDP markets around. We don't have a lot of legacy businesses that we have to drag along with this. I look at China by itself, and largely, we're a Hershey's business there and more specifically, we're a Hershey's Kisses business there. As we expand our category in our portfolio within the category that gives us a tremendous amount of runway. We advertise in -- like I think only about 20% or 25% of the cities that the leading competitor in the market does and so as we continue to expand that and our household penetration grows. We can talk about what's the right GDP for China, but if you think about an emerging, middle class and our portfolio over time, we have a tremendous amount of runway there. And so as we execute against our business model in a thoughtful, planful, we have this very precious North American business that I have a tremendous amount of confidence in, I think that our guidance is absolutely right for the long-term. We want to continue to be acquisitive. And so I think we've got a great future.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phillis. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. J.P. Bilbrey, President and CEO; and Bert Alfonso, President, International, and Head of Mergers and Acquisitions, will provide y
componenttext:
Thank you, Phillis. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to The Hershey Company's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. J.P. Bilbrey, President and CEO; and Bert Alfonso, President, International, and Head of Mergers and Acquisitions, will provide you with an overview of our results, followed by a Q&A session.
Let me remind everyone listening that today's conference call may contain statements which are forward looking. These statements are based on current expectations which are subject to risk and uncertainty. Actual results may vary materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements because of factors such as those listed in this morning's press release and in our 10-K for 2013 filed with the SEC.
If you have not seen the press release, a copy is posted on our corporate website, in the investor relations section.
Included in the press release is a consolidated balance sheet and a summary of consolidated statements of income prepared in accordance with GAAP. Within the Note section of the press release, we have provided adjusted pro forma reconciliations of select income statement line items quantitatively reconciled to GAAP. The company uses these non-GAAP measures as key metrics for evaluating performance internally. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to replace the presentation of financial results in accordance with GAAP. Rather, the company believes that presentation of earnings, excluding certain items, provides additional information to investors to facilitate the comparison of past and present operations.
As a result, we will discuss 2014 fourth quarter results, excluding net pretax charges of $32.5 million or $0.13 per share diluted, primarily related to a noncash trademark impairment charge and onetime [ph] disposal of $24.8 million or $0.10 per share diluted and business realignment costs of $4.7 million or $0.02 per share diluted. Our discussion of any future projections will also exclude the impact of these net charges.
With that out of the way, let me turn the call over to J.P. Bilbrey.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning to all of you on the phone and webcast.In 2014, Hershey made progress against its strategic initiatives. U.S. CMG xAOC+C market share reached 31.4%, up 0.3 share points versus last year. We acquired Shanghai Golden Monkey, which more than d
componenttext:
Good morning to all of you on the phone and webcast.
In 2014, Hershey made progress against its strategic initiatives. U.S. CMG xAOC+C market share reached 31.4%, up 0.3 share points versus last year. We acquired Shanghai Golden Monkey, which more than doubles the company's presence in China. We expanded into snacks and adjacencies with the launch of Hershey’s Spreads and the related Snacksters Graham Dippers. And we sourced 30% of our cocoa needs from certified and sustainable cocoa farms, putting us in a solid position to deliver on our 100% goal by 2020.
There were also challenges. In 2014, we believe lower retail store traffic, changes in consumer spending patterns as a result of the SNAP program and a more competitive snacking environment were contributing factors that impacted how consumers participated in the snack segment. This resulted in fourth quarter and full year sales and earnings that were below our expectations. Specifically, growth in snacking alternatives and an evolving retail landscape are impacting what consumers buy and where and how they make purchases. Higher-income consumers continue to ask for simple ingredients, health and wellness. And millennials view brands and brand attributes beyond traditional transparency to include social responsibility. They are also interacting with media differently.
Now let me share with you some of the things that we're doing to address this. Our R&D and innovation teams continue to make progress on new confectionery and snack products that enable us to offer great confectionery products and increase the breadth of our portfolio. Later this year, the Club Channel will be introducing Brookside dark chocolate fruit-and-nut snack bars.
Building on our snacks and adjacencies strategy, earlier today, we announced that we entered into an agreement to acquire KRAVE Jerky, which enables us to enter the rapidly growing meat snacks category. We're really excited about this acquisition and the opportunity to participate in the $2.5 billion meat snacks category that's growing at a double-figure rate.
While snacks and adjacencies is a lever in our long-term sales algorithm, we're very focused on confectionery. It's who we are and it's our namesake. We have a lot of CMG innovation this year that I'll talk to in a moment, but we also have a meaningful new product pipeline that gives me confidence that innovation can continue to contribute at least one point of growth to our net sales algorithm on an annual basis. So I remain bullish on the CMG category and our ability to keep increasing market share.
As it relates to simple ingredients and transparency, we've actually done a lot of work here. We haven't leveraged what we've done, as our plan is to move a large portion of our portfolio in this direction. We're building the capability and have made progress to source non-GMO sugar and RSBT-free (sic) [rBST-free] milk for products in the United States. We've already begun this work with key sourcing suppliers here in the U.S., and we'll have more news on this later in the year.
On the media front, we expect that advertising and related consumer promotion will increase at a rate greater than sales. Included in this is a greater proportion of investment in digital advertising on programs consumers view on their mobile devices via traditional networks, user-generated content and sources like BuzzFeed. So we're making investments that will benefit the company in the near and long term. And we'll have more on this at CAGNY, so let's move on.
I was satisfied with improved results in the convenience store, large mass retail and dollar store channels, especially in the second half of the year. However, FDMx nonseasonal candy performance was not in line with our initial plans. Lower retail store traffic, greater levels of in-store activity by broader snacking manufacturers and continued economic challenges for a segment of consumers in these channels impacted our nonseasonal candy growth.
Looking at total xAOC+C-store retail takeaway. U.S. marketplace performance sequentially improved throughout the year. Hershey fourth quarter retail takeaway of 3.8% was greater than the category growth of 2.2%, resulting in a market share gain of 0.5 points. Marketplace performance was greater than 4Q net sales given solid Halloween and holiday sales, a portion of which shipped in the third quarter; the timing of the buying-in related to the price increase, as a portion of third quarter net sales would have normally occurred in the fourth quarter; and the lapping of the strong year-ago period when select retailers increased inventory levels.
Driving our fourth quarter takeaway results were improvements in convenience stores, large mass retail and dollar stores. These were the channels where many of our second half initiatives were focused, so I was pleased with the results. The programming and execution changes we made in the FDMx and Club Channel simply require a longer lead time to impact in-store merchandising activity, hence our sales mix and lower-than-forecast category growth impacted profitability and margins.
Let me now talk about 2015, where our focus will be on restoring our U.S. momentum.
We have a solid lineup of new products that will bring variety, news and excitement to the category. In addition to the carryover benefit of Brookside Crunchy Clusters and Reese's Spreads, we're also launching Kit Kat White Minis, Hershey's caramels, Ice Breakers Cool Blasts Chews, Reese's Spreads Snacksters Graham Dippers and some other yet-to-be-announced new products. Additionally, the Reese's brand is leveraging its NCAA relationship and has become an official sponsor of ESPN college football game day. These initiatives are tied into customer-specific merchandising programs and big core brands that should result in higher-quality merchandising versus last year.
Additionally, we're increasing our reach as we're adding incremental headcount to our sales force that will result in hours in store being up mid-single digits. We'll complement this with increased levels of advertising that I mentioned earlier.
We believe the investments we're making across our business positions us for future growth. The dynamics of the confectionery category, impulsivity, conversion rate at checkouts, season multiple-pack types are all an advantage. As a result, in 2015, we anticipate that the plans we have in place will help mitigate the volume elasticity related to the price increase, and it will outpace the category and again gain market share.
Let me now provide you with some information on our international business.
For the full year, our international net sales increased nearly 15%, including the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates and positive contribution of about $54 million from Shanghai Golden Monkey. Excluding SGM and unfavorable FX, international net sales increased 10%, a solid number but less than our expectations due to macroeconomic headwinds that have yet to subside and will most likely remain a challenge this year. The Hershey-Golden Monkey integration work is underway and on track.
In 2015, we'll distribute acquired confectionery and protein-based bean curd snacks into the China modern trade, and we expect to have deeper Tier 2 city coverage of some Hershey chocolate products. We're also leveraging newly acquired manufacturing capabilities. In China, Brazil, Mexico and India, we've made solid progress against our planned initiatives of investing in go-to-market capabilities and portfolio expansion. In select markets, we launched Reese's, and it's off to a good start. Additionally, we're testing additional products, as we look to build out our global brands over the next few years.
Therefore, in 2015, including a negative impact from foreign currency exchange rates and excluding the impact of M&A, we expect international net sales growth to increase around 10%. Including SGM, reported international net sales are expected to be around $1.2 billion by the end of 2015.
By country, our chocolate business in China had a solid year. Chocolate category growth in 2014 was about 12%. Historically, the chocolate category has increased 10% to 11% in the fourth quarter. However, it slowed to around 8% as we see less gifting behind the government policy changes.
Hershey fourth quarter retail takeaway of about 20% was less than our expectation. Importantly, our market share in Q4 increased a full point to around 11%. In Mexico, chocolate category growth in the modern trade 2014 was around 1%. The category and consumer struggled during the year, although trends were better in the second half of the year, with chocolate category growth of 3%. But this is still below the historical growth rate of 7% to 8%. Hershey Mexico chocolate retail takeaway for the year was up around 2%, resulting in a market share gain of 0.3 points. We expect 2015 to be better than last year, albeit in a continuing challenging environment.
Our performance in Brazil sequentially improved as the year progressed. For the year, Brazil chocolate category growth was 1% versus about 5% in recent years. Hershey retail takeaway was up 2%. Our performance was driven by our Hershey tablet bar growth and the launch of Reese's. We'll look to build on this in 2015.
Now to wrap up. Our consumer and customer plans as well as our investment profile for 2015 clearly reflect the learnings from 2014. Our plans are focused, and the investment profile is concentrated in the areas to leverage Hershey's advantage brands and go-to-market strength. Investment in our brands, innovation and capabilities, as well as an increase across all channels and merchandising and programming, positions the company to compete effectively in confectionery and across the broader snack continuum. We believe these investments should generate organic net sales growth on constant currency sales, excluding M&A and FX impacts, of around 4% to 6% in 2015. This is less than our previous estimate and reflects the macroeconomic headwinds in international markets and the slowly improving U.S. nonseasonal trends.
I typically just talk to net sales with or without M&A. However, when we established our long-term sales target, we didn't anticipate the U.S. dollar being this strong. Given the current backdrop, we expect foreign exchange rates to be greater than our previous estimate and be about 1 percentage point unfavorable in 2015. We estimate that the net contribution from acquisitions and divestitures will be around 2.5 points.
We continue to focus on growth initiatives and margin opportunities behind continuous productivity-improvement initiatives. With the conclusion of the Project Next Century program, in 2015, we'll focus on where the next largest opportunities are for future incremental productivity and cost savings. A portion of any particular savings from this assessment would be reinvested in our CMG and snacks business to accelerate our growth. And we'll provide more information on this at the upcoming CAGNY conference.
I will now turn it over to Bert, who will provide some additional details on our financial results. Bert?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, J.P. And good morning to everyone. It's a pleasure to be here to talk about our results as well as some of the recent M&A activity. As Mark mentioned, I've been very close to all of this, as I have responsibility for the M&A function as w
componenttext:
Well, thank you, J.P. And good morning to everyone. It's a pleasure to be here to talk about our results as well as some of the recent M&A activity. As Mark mentioned, I've been very close to all of this, as I have responsibility for the M&A function as well as our international segment.
So let's get started.
Fourth quarter net sales of $2 billion increased 2.7% versus last year, generating adjusted earnings per share diluted of $1.04, an increased 20.9%. As J.P. stated, the sales increase was lower than our expectations, primarily due to lower retail store traffic. Net price realization, mostly in the U.S., was a 3.1-point benefit. Excluding Shanghai Golden Monkey, volume was off 2.3 points due to price elasticity associated with the U.S. price increase announced in July and lower-than-expected nonseasonal sales. The Shanghai Golden Monkey acquisition was a 2.7-point benefit, and foreign currency was a 0.8-point headwind.
Q4 U.S. seasonal sales, primarily driven by holiday, increased high single digits on a percentage basis versus last year. Full year seasonal sales were a bp higher given a later Easter in 2014. Conversely, Easter is 15 days shorter in 2015 and will be a headwind this year. From a marketplace perspective, our Halloween and holiday market share increased 0.9 points and 1.1 points, respectively.
International net sales in the fourth quarter increased 28%, including a benefit of about $54 million related to the Shanghai Golden Monkey acquisition. Excluding Shanghai Golden Monkey, international net sales increased 8% as reported and 11% on a constant currency basis, as unfavorable FX was greater than anticipated. Macroeconomic headwinds in Q4 led to international sales being lower than our expectations.
Turning to margins. Fourth quarter adjusted gross margin increased by 30 basis points. The increase was driven by net price realization, slightly favorable input costs and supply chain productivity, partially offset by unfavorable sales mix and other supply chain costs.
Fourth quarter adjusted earnings before interest and taxes or EBIT increased 17.5% versus last year, generating an adjusted EBIT margin of 18.7%, a 240 basis point increase versus last year. The increase was due to higher gross margin and lower SM&A costs that declined about 5% due primarily to lower employee-related costs. In Q4, advertising was at about the same as last year. As we said throughout the year, advertising GRPs were up mid-single digits on a percentage basis versus 2013.
Now let me provide a bit more detail on our international business.
China continues to drive international net sales growth and, excluding Shanghai Golden Monkey, increased about 35% in both the fourth quarter and for the full year. We anticipate a similar profile in 2015. I am very pleased with the progress we continue to make in China and remain optimistic regarding confectionery growth in both the modern and traditional trade. We will continue to expand our selling capabilities and expect growth in 2015 to be balanced between velocity and distribution gains. We will also expand cross-selling of products between Shanghai Golden Monkey and Hershey China in the coming year. And finally, we were very pleased with our 1.6-point share gain in chocolate in 2014.
In Brazil, Q4 net sales were about the same as last year on a reported basis and increased about 12% on a constant currency basis. For the full year, net sales declined about 3% on a reported basis and increased about 7% on a constant currency basis versus last year. Despite the difficult category environment, we were pleased with a small share gain of 0.1 points. In 2015, we're exploring other go-to-market options together with our current JV partner Bauducco. Our distribution JV with Bauducco has enabled us to double our market share in the last few years. However, we are considering having total control of the selling and distribution function to give us more flexibly and investment options.
In Mexico, fourth quarter net sales declined 6% on a reported basis and were flat on a constant currency basis versus last year. For the full year, net sales declined 8% on a reported basis and 4% on a constant currency basis compared to 2013. Again, our chocolate performance was favorable, with a 0.3-point share gain driven by both velocity and distribution gains. Trends in Mexico are getting better, and we expect continued improvement throughout 2015, although still below the historical growth rates.
We have made solid progress against our international strategic plans. We remain committed to our core markets. And we'll continue to make the necessary investments to build distribution capability, brand equity; and drive trial and repeat purchases.
Moving down the P&L.
The fourth quarter interest expense of $21 million was about the same as last year. For the full year, interest expense was $85 million and in line with our expectations. And for 2015, we expect interest expense to be $75 million to $80 million.
The adjusted tax rate for the fourth quarter and the full year was 34.5%, in line with our estimates. In 2015, we expect the adjusted tax rate to be similar to last year.
In the fourth quarter, with -- average shares outstanding on a diluted basis were approximately 223.5 million, leading to adjusted earnings per share diluted of $1.04, an increase of 20.9%.
Full year adjusted EBIT increased 5.8% versus last year, generating an adjusted EBIT margin of 19.6% or a 40 basis point increase. The increase was driven by lower SG&A.
Turning now to the balance sheet and to our cash flow.
At the end of the fourth quarter, net trading capital increased versus last year's fourth quarter by $240 million. Accounts receivable was higher by $119 million, primarily due to the Shanghai Golden Monkey acquisition, Lotte China consolidation and traditional credit terms provided to our largest customers in China. Inventory was higher by $141 million due to Shanghai Golden Monkey and Lotte, as well as higher raw material inventory levels, primarily dairy that we mentioned in the last quarter. And accounts payable increased by $21 million.
Capital additions, including software, were $139 million in the fourth quarter and $379 million for the full year, in line with our expectations. This included capital related to our manufacturing facility that we are building in Johor, Malaysia. In 2015, we expect CapEx to be in the $375 million to $400 million range.
The company repurchased 2 million of outstanding shares in the fourth quarter and 202 million for the full year. Repurchases of $125 million were against the prior authorization, and $77 million were against the current $250 million repurchase authorization approved in February of 2014. In addition, 32 million of common shares were repurchased in Q4 to replace shares issued in connection with the exercise of stock options.
Depreciation and amortization was $59 million in the fourth quarter and $212 million for the full year, in line with expectations.
Dividends paid during the quarter were $115 million and $440 million for the full year.
Cash and short-term investments at the end of fourth quarter were $471 million, slightly below our expectations due to the lower sales.
The company remains well positioned to fund our dividends, working capital, capital expenditure requirements and acquisitions.
Let me close by providing context into our 2015 outlook. As J.P. summarized, in 2015, we have a solid pipeline of targeted innovation, merchandising and programming that can drive pack type and channel growth. In addition, advertising and related consumer marketing expense is expected to increase at a rate greater than net sales growth. As a result, we expect 2015 net sales to increase from 5.5% to 7.5%, including the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates and a net contribution from acquisitions and divestitures of about 2.5 points. This includes the acquisition of Shanghai Golden Monkey and Allan Candy that closed in the fourth quarter, as well as the agreement entered into the last month to acquire KRAVE Jerky and divest Mauna Loa. We expect the KRAVE and Mauna Loa transactions to close in the first quarter.
Excluding net acquisitions and divestitures, sales are expected to increase 3% to 5%. This is lower than our previous estimate due to the continued macroeconomic headwinds as well as greater-than-initial estimates related to unfavorable foreign currency exchange rates. And we expect foreign exchange impact to be greater than our previous estimate and have an unfavorable impact of approximately one percentage point on our full year net sales growth.
We continue to have a significant focus on gross margin and expect the previously announced pricing action as well as productivity and cost savings to result in 2015 gross margin expansion of 135 to 145 basis points.
Adjusted earnings per share diluted are expected to increase 8% to 10%, and that includes dilution from acquisitions and divestitures of $0.03 to $0.05 per share.
Before we open up for Q&A, just a couple of thoughts on the first quarter. Remember that Easter is 2 weeks shorter this year and being sold on at the old price points, which will pressure gross margin. Our international sales profile is similar to prior years, with annual growth primarily driven by second half. Therefore, total first quarter net sales, including M&A, are expected to be around the low end of our annual sales target. Additionally, brand building as well as investments in selling capabilities will ramp up in Q1.
Given all these moving parts, EPS growth is expected to be pressured in the first quarter and higher as the year progresses.
I thank you for your time this morning, and we'll now take questions.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, there's a couple -- sure. There's a couple of things. And we are encouraged with some of the things we're seeing as we deconstruct the weekly data. So you're correct. The nonseasonal FDMx sales has been the biggest drag in our business. So we fe
componenttext: Yes, yes, there's a couple -- sure. There's a couple of things. And we are encouraged with some of the things we're seeing as we deconstruct the weekly data. So you're correct. The nonseasonal FDMx sales has been the biggest drag in our business. So we feel good about the fact that, in the fourth quarter, we saw improvement. We continued to grow ahead of the category. And it was really a result of, we think, improved focus in merchandising in specific channels. In FDMx, it's a slower build there because the planning cycle is also different, but there's a couple of things that we're seeing. And if we look at the weekly data and when you get the most recent quad, you're going to see that we're making good progression from a share standpoint. We think that reflects some of the changes we made in merchandising. One of the other things that we're seeing is trips continue to be negative, although they're getting better but negative, and of course that continues to affect the ends of consumer because this is all everyday business; because if people aren't in the store, you lose that instant consumable piece. So we're very focused on that. There's a piece of data that I recently looked at for our brand specifically that within the trip, there's an increase in actual purchase size. So the trips that we're getting purchase size is actually up, but the one caveat I'll make with that is keep in mind, with the fourth quarter, you have some seasonal influence, so that can be part of it, but in the weekly data, and this is all home skin information, we do have some real encouragement there. So I feel good about what I'm beginning to see. Anecdotally, as you talk to retailers, I would say that I'm hearing some of those same kinds of sentiments echoed. And then of course, we all are aware that the consumers have a lot of pressure at the bottom of the economic pyramid. And it's still yet to be seen how that consumer participates in the market, but for the total, I think I'm encouraged.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bryan, I think you started the question by sort of comparing what we were thinking in the third quarter versus more recently. And if you think about the international side, 0.5 points is really just incremental drag from FX. So back then, we were thinking
componenttext: Bryan, I think you started the question by sort of comparing what we were thinking in the third quarter versus more recently. And if you think about the international side, 0.5 points is really just incremental drag from FX. So back then, we were thinking closer to 0.5 points. Today, we're firmly at 1 point, and we'll see where that goes. Hopefully, the dollar starts to stabilize a bit. When we look at the international business, we're probably closer to around 13% back then, and we've lowered it to around 10%, as J.P. mentioned. The macroeconomy has gotten a little tougher in places like Brazil and Mexico. We saw a little bit of a slowdown in China in the fourth quarter, but we worry less about that. A lot -- we've had a lot of momentum going into Chinese New Year. But certainly, what J.P. talked about in terms of some pickup on the everyday business and some -- and a little bit lower expectations, at least for 2015, in international is what's made the biggest difference. We've also had a little pressure on our export business, which was not huge. It is very profitable. And as you can imagine, the currency into some of these markets also has some impact.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And again, just so as we kind of tie that all together, does the guidance assume that things really improve? Or do we -- or would improvement in both of those areas be upside to where our revenue guidance is?
componenttext: That's helpful. And again, just so as we kind of tie that all together, does the guidance assume that things really improve? Or do we -- or would improvement in both of those areas be upside to where our revenue guidance is?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're hoping for, although we not have baked it into our plans, gradual improvement, but we would say back half versus first half.
componenttext: Yes, we're hoping for, although we not have baked it into our plans, gradual improvement, but we would say back half versus first half.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: So I have 3 questions but they're all kind of related. The first is, what percent of your North American volume do you assume is going to be under the new price increase this year? You mentioned Easter wasn't about. What percent would that be? Related to that and secondly is, is there some negative mix factor I'm missing that why gross margins would only be up 120 to 130 of rough gross margin blend? We get this magnitude of price increase. Your #2 commodity, dairy, is now in free fall. And I know you've bought forward to some extent. That's understandable, but it looks to me like your cost bucket item is flat to down exiting the year. Like, is there something I'm missing as to why that margin expansion is so small and how that might pace over the year? And then third and finally, can you give us a sense what kind of volume you're thinking overly [ph] associated with this guidance? So is it right [ph] to understand that there's somewhat this manufacturing deleverage kind of like we saw in the fourth quarter?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, let's -- yes, let me kind of take the pricing one, first, and then I'll let Bert talk a little bit about the gross margin. The best way to think about the pricing is that, as we move through the year, there are still some activities that are under t
componenttext: Okay, let's -- yes, let me kind of take the pricing one, first, and then I'll let Bert talk a little bit about the gross margin. The best way to think about the pricing is that, as we move through the year, there are still some activities that are under the old price certainly around the seasonal business, so you'll begin to see that have a greater impact in Q2 and Q3. And then as you think about getting through the end of '15, we continue to model the elasticity at about a 1:1 rate in terms of volume and price, so by the time we get to the first quarter of 2016, our modeling would suggest that we're back to a whole environment or back to 100 in terms of volume contribution to our growth. So that's the way I would think about it broadly. There's a lot of movement still, but as we look at some of our channel modeling, there's nothing that we're seeing that would cause us to believe that it would be any different than how we've planned it. And as you know, when we were increasing advertising in a very rapid rate back in 2008, '09 and 2011, there might have been a little bit of a faster conversion rate, but we think the way we've currently modeled it is probably about right.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me try to sort of fill you in on your question around gross margin. As we think about our gross margin expansion, we're expecting 135 to 145 basis points. We're coming off a year when we're actually down on gross margin first time in a long time. We d
componenttext: Let me try to sort of fill you in on your question around gross margin. As we think about our gross margin expansion, we're expecting 135 to 145 basis points. We're coming off a year when we're actually down on gross margin first time in a long time. We did start to see a pickup in the fourth quarter slightly below where we thought. When you look at our year-on-year commodities, well, I won't talk specifically about hedging program, but clearly, cocoa is still on average at higher prices than it was in our '14 standard. And that's really a function of as we roll out our commodity program in an environment of increasing costs, and we've seen cocoa increase pretty dramatically. Obviously, you have -- you may have some of your lower hedges rolling off and are buying into a little bit higher market. So while we've seen some improvement recently, and that's good, we still have cocoa that's higher than '14 levels. So that does have some -- a bit of an impact in terms of how you're thinking about the expansion. And the other thing is, as J.P. mentioned, our profile for 2015 is driven by pricing. So we're expecting 5 to 6 points of pricing and 1 to 2 points of lower volume. And that lower volume does pressure our absorption in the plants, and so you don't get the full benefit of that until, as you get later in the year, as J.P. mentioned, we start to recover the pre-price-increase volume. So some volume impact as we work through the price elasticity. And whilst some commodities are clearly in a better place, like dairy and sugar, we do still have higher cocoa prices year-on-year. So that's helping to mitigate to some degree what might be otherwise larger gross margin expansion.

componenttext: In the first quarter, we certainly have the mix of Easter at the lower -- or old prices, right, because that particular season is still protected. Once you get beyond that, then you have seasons. So you do have that. And J.P. already talked about the everyday business is starting to improve of -- but the more that improves quicker, the better we look on a mix basis. We did have, as was already explained, not as good a mix in '14 as we thought we would just based on the everyday. So certainly a first quarter impact on Easter and old prices and then improving throughout the year as pricing kicks in.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes, [indiscernible]. Jon, just -- it's Mark. Just one thing. So you would expect that we will have the most pricing then in the second and the third quarter. And looking at it total company for the full year, you're probably thinking -- think about it like 5 to 6 points of price; volume off, whatever, 1.5 to 2 points because most -- a lot of the international business is all going to be volume driven. And then you've got about 1 point of FX. So that's, I guess, how to think about the full year.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So a couple of quick questions. It was a little alarming to hear about how the candy, mint and gum category growth has slowed to about 1.7% in 2014 and how there might be some encroachments from other snacking categories. Are you worried that some of thos
componenttext: So a couple of quick questions. It was a little alarming to hear about how the candy, mint and gum category growth has slowed to about 1.7% in 2014 and how there might be some encroachments from other snacking categories. Are you worried that some of those types of shifts maybe more structural, I guess? Are you seeing -- are you worried about smaller brands continuing to come up? And then my second question is actually more about the acquisition strategy from here. As you bought the KRAVE business and move from -- clearly into a very different snacking category, might we see more of those types of moves so that you end up sort of bulking up in snack categories that are maybe more in line with where the consumer is heading?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Alexia, to your first question, around the category, my answer would be no. I don't think there's anything structural that's going on here. One interesting piece of data is just household penetration actually went up for our brands in 2014. And so I think
componenttext: Alexia, to your first question, around the category, my answer would be no. I don't think there's anything structural that's going on here. One interesting piece of data is just household penetration actually went up for our brands in 2014. And so I think the thing that we're seeing is potentially several-fold. So 2014, there were a lot of moving parts in terms of macroeconomic influences on consumers, so we see that. The trips piece for a business like ours which has this everyday component is, certainly, it impacted people already in stores. And I think that is more -- there's a real consumer strata influence there that I think has to be dealt with. And then in terms of let's just talk about the consumer themselves: I do believe there's an evolution always happening with consumers and the relationships they have with brands. I think some of the smaller brands have done a very good job of resonating with some of the on-trend things that consumers talk about. And we can talk separately about KRAVE here in a second, of why we think that's an on-trend product uniquely positioned within that particular segment. But as we saw takeaway improve throughout the year, we felt we became a more competitive company responding to some of the -- just things that are happening within the category. And consumers, of course, have broader choices. What we see happening almost everywhere, and I'm very optimistic about how this plays to our strengths, is that snacking and portable snacking is not just a short-term event. This is really a trend, and it's becoming a habit. And if you look at the way the number of meals people have during the today, they have broader options on the menu of how to participate in that. We just have to be competitive. And we have to be competitive with the brands we have that are within the core of The Hershey Company, our confectionery products. We're expanding brands like Brookside, which has a nice halo effect of goodness. And then we also see ourselves, as we've talked about, expanding across a broader snacking continuum. And even if you talk, even if you think about China and a brand, our bean curd, in China, that's a product that brings protein. It's on trend in terms of being a "snacking on the go" brand. So we just see that being more and more important in terms of consumer trend. And so as a company, we have to adapt to where the consumer is headed. We talked about simple ingredients with GMO-free. If you think about a chocolate bar, there's really only 4 components in a chocolate bar. So we should be talking about the simplicity of that in responding to the transparency that consumers want, and we're doing that. So I'm very optimistic about all of those things. Why don't we let -- Alexia, you were -- you set us up nicely to talk about KRAZE. I -- Michele Buck, who's the President of North America and was very, very involved with the acquisition for KRAZE, is here, so why don't I give her a chance to just talk for a couple of minutes about the acquisition?

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, J.P. As J.P. mentioned, we're seeing consumers continue to snack more and graze throughout the day. And as such, their snacking needs are really evolving. And we are going to be focused, as we continue to look at the growth of our company as
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, J.P. As J.P. mentioned, we're seeing consumers continue to snack more and graze throughout the day. And as such, their snacking needs are really evolving. And we are going to be focused, as we continue to look at the growth of our company as a snack company, in how we meet those needs. One of the areas that we've seen a lot of consumer interest in is portable nutrition and protein-based snacking. So as we look at that marketplace, clearly, one of the categories that's really meeting consumers' needs is meat snacks. Meat snacks is a category that is one of the fastest growing, growing double digit in the U.S. this past year and over the past several years. Household penetration is expanding. So household penetration is only about 31%, but it continues to grow, grew 2 points this past year. So clearly, it's meeting a lot of consumer needs. And as we looked at that category,  KRAVE was interesting to us because KRAVE is really playing in the fastest-growing segment of the meat snacks category, the better-for-you premium segment. So we really like the brand. We think it has tremendous potential. The product proposition has a unique point of difference with a great taste, a texture. It's a culinary-inspired kind of profile. And we think that there's a lot of potential. And they continue to bring new consumers into the meat snacks category in the marketplace for us to leverage Hershey's strengths in supply chain, consumer insights in retail to really drive the business. So we couldn't be more excited about how it will continue to help us to meet consumers' needs as we stay very focused, of course, on winning in our category.

componenttext: I guess, 2 quick things. One, J.P., would be -- and maybe you'll cover this a little bit more at CAGNY, but I think it's important just to cover the topic. I certainly appreciate the evolution of where consumers are going and Hershey's desire to sort of cover off on that a bit more with snacking adjacencies and such, but the last time Hershey did this, albeit in a different set of sort of broader snacking categories, the execution really wasn't where the company wanted it to be. The sustainability of some of those items, whether it was cookies in the C-store, nuts, things like that, weren't exactly, I guess, as sustainable. So is there something now that is different about capabilities, the way you're planning for these sorts of things, whether it's KRAVE or things beyond that, that make you feel a lot better about the sustainability of it? And then I've just got a quick follow-up.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Andrew, I think the biggest thing in my mind is the ability for us to execute against, I think, a clearer business model today than we've had in the past. I think that -- if you look at what we're doing in China and we're going at a planful, thought
componenttext: Sure. Andrew, I think the biggest thing in my mind is the ability for us to execute against, I think, a clearer business model today than we've had in the past. I think that -- if you look at what we're doing in China and we're going at a planful, thoughtful pace to execute against the right R&D, the right distribution, the consumer insights and supporting it with advertising, et cetera, I think that's where we're probably doing a much better job today than we have in the past. And so admittedly, not all things work perfectly, but I think that we have a clearer sense of how we want to execute against these things that I expect us to be successful.

headline: The Hershey Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as we thought about just the category, we certainly plan to grow market share within the category. We think, long term, the 3% to 4% growth rate for the category is still the right way to think about it. With these things, sometimes, it's a bit abov
componenttext: Well, as we thought about just the category, we certainly plan to grow market share within the category. We think, long term, the 3% to 4% growth rate for the category is still the right way to think about it. With these things, sometimes, it's a bit above. Sometimes, it's a bit below. But as we've seen some improvement over the -- as I talked earlier about, the quad and the weeks, et cetera, we think that it's still a good planning stance for this year to think about positive category growth. And the most important thing is, in that environment, we have to win.
